script: Before we move on, I want to play you something.
We've had a lot of incredible artists on this show over the past few weeks, and almost every single one of them has talked about pricing.
So we pulled the three best moments — three artists, three turning points, one lesson.
hostIntro.presenterNotes: Deliver with a slight pause before 'Watch this.' Let it feel like a TV moment. The bumper transition should feel intentional. Energy: reflective, building anticipation.

clips.description: Marcus on pricing his first big piece and realizing he was losing money
clips.transcriptSnippet: I quoted $200 for a full sleeve session and it took me 8 hours. I made $25 an hour. My barber makes more than that. That was my wake-up call.
clips.hostBridge: Twenty-five dollars an hour. For custom artwork that stays on someone's body forever. Marcus figured it out. But he's not the only one.

clips.description: Sarah on how raising prices actually increased her bookings
clips.transcriptSnippet: When I raised my rate from $120 to $200 an hour, I thought I'd lose half my clients. Instead, I got BETTER clients. People who valued the work, showed up on time, tipped well. The cheap clients were the most difficult ones anyway.
clips.hostBridge: Better clients. Better work. Better life. And all she had to do was charge what she was worth. One more.

clips.description: Marcus Rodriguez on pricing strategy for a premium brand
clips.transcriptSnippet: I don't negotiate. Ever. My price is my price. If someone asks for a discount, I politely say: 'I understand budgets are real. Here are some great artists who work at a lower price point.' And I refer them. No hard feelings. But I never devalue my own work.

script: Three different artists. Three different styles. Three different cities.
Same lesson: know your worth, and don't apologize for it.
If any of that hit home, stick around — we've got actionable pricing strategies coming up next that'll help you put this into practice this week.
hostOutro.presenterNotes: Deliver directly to camera. Slow, confident. The 'same lesson' line should land like a thesis statement. The CTA into the next segment should feel like momentum, not a hard sell.

Display lower-third with source guest name/episode during each clip. Music: subtle underscore during host bridges, silent during clips.
